abstracts.cdata!:
The Tanzania social action funds
            (TASAF), takes an annual budget of 15 million dollars and
            spreads it in small doses across more than 2,200 similar
            projects in the poorest rural areas of the country,
            including the Zanzibar archipelago. Drawing on a national
            database of poverty statistics, the fund has pinpointed the
            poorest third of Tanzania's districts for its programs.
            Rather than have bureaucrats in the capital chose which
            services and programs go where, the agency goes straight to
            the villages and asks them what they need. The villagers
            take the helm from designing the project to making it a
            reality. In Tanzania, a government-backed community
            development fund is asking some of the countrys poorest
            villages to contribute 20 percent toward project costs.
